children.text: All the work done in a function is only accessible in that function. In other words, if we make a variable in a function, the outer program can't access it; the only way to transmit its value is to return it.

children.caption: Code showing the scope of variables

children.text: has a local scope and is accessible only within the function
On the other hand, if a function is told to use a variable it hasn't defined, the function automatically looks in the
(outside the function at the top level) to see if the variable exists there.

! It's unlikely that you'll want to use this, but good to know for debugging.
You can think of the scope of a variable as being like its last name. For example, consider the following code:
exists in both the local and the global scope, but the two
Analogy: knowing two people both named Andrew. They have the same first name, but different last names.
In the code above, the last name of the function's x would be tested, while the last name of the top-level x would be global.
In general, it's best to keep variable names different to avoid confusion.
